text: - Hi, I am Kevin Lewis.
Welcome back to our masterclass
on data governance from AWS.

And now, I'd like to
talk about distribution

of responsibilities as it
relates to data governance.
There is a ongoing perpetual
debate challenge

pendulum swing as it
relates to what elements

of the data governance
program should be centralized
and what elements should be decentralized.
And we can make a mistake

in both directions that
we have to be careful of.
So, let's do a little bit of history here.
So, really, in the,

what was called the data
warehousing movement,
the idea was to centralize primarily.

There was a lot of fragmented
data being developed

and being deployed in
a bunch of different,
what were called data marts.
And
the idea was to take a lot of that data,

bring it together, so
that it can be reused,
and so it could link data

from across multiple
domains. (sharply inhales)
And this was all well and good.

But then, as this centralized
program proceeded,
the data warehouse grew more and more.

The program grew more and
more. The teams grew larger.
And it actually became somewhat unwieldy
in many organizations.
It became somewhat of a bottleneck,

because if someone
wanted to deploy new data
to support some new business initiative,

they would have to go through
this centralized program.

And again, it was perceived
as slowing down the success

of the initiatives that
were being supported.
So, the idea was to split that up,

to split up the architecture
under the name of data mesh.
There's been other names,

but the idea is to take
this centralized program,
centralized architecture,
and reintroduce a more decentralization.
And so, we can think of
in what we call the modern data community,
we can think of three major elements here.
We can think of data producers

who produce data that needs
to be used by consumers.
So, consumers is the second group.

And then, we can think
about the central data team.
And so, let's talk about (clears throat)
the appropriate distribution

of responsibilities
across these three groups.

Again, we can make mistakes
in both directions.
In order to decentralize, we can overdo it
and return to a much more fragmented place

that we were trying to get
away from to begin with.
So, we need to make sure
we're not swinging the pendulum
too far one way or the other.

So, let's talk about the
role of each of these
and what we wanna lead towards.

Let's start by talking
about data consumers.
So, we heard the term self-service a lot
and that's a good thing.
We want to empower our end user community.
We wanna empower application developers.
However, we do not want to overburden them
with responsibilities

for data management that
they should not have to do.
We wanna empower them to, for example,
collect data and experiment with it,

to decide if this data
has any business value.
They should be able to build sandboxes.

They should be able to
ask business questions
that they're authorized to ask.
This should be the kind of self-service
that should be available to them.
But if they're curating basic sales data,
revenue data, inventory, claims policy,
all the things that we've talked about
that are central to an organization

that should be in a condition
that's usable for them,
then we've gone from self-service
to overburdening them with responsibility.
So, what is the appropriate role

for consumers for data
management practices
within a healthy data governance program?
It is to empower them

to take on new data
sources, to experiment,

to leverage the data they
need to be successful.
But it should not be about

doing basic core data
management capabilities
that should be done for them.
That is what we wanna push into more

of the central data team
and for data producers.
Now, let's talk about data producers
and their role in all of this.
So, remember that we talked

about all of those data
management practices,

understanding data, curating
data, protecting data,

and the specific elements
underneath each of those.
We want to empower the data producers
to develop their own data products
that are contributed
into the overall data analytics ecosystem.
And so, they should be able

to do as much of those
data management practices
as possible in their data.
So, again, like claims or policy data.
There should be groups that are empowered
to look after that data
and it should be enabled with the tools

and capabilities to manage
that data appropriately.

Now, let's talk about the
role of the central team.
And this is where we can really go too far
one way or the other.
Again, we don't wanna overcentralize.

We want to empower the
data producers especially
to take care of their own data domain
that they're responsible for

and to create data products
that they're responsible for.

But what happens when we
wanna thread data together
across data products?

We've used the example
of customer experience.

We talk about understanding
the interaction
that our company has with a customer

across various channels
and across transactions.

If it's a financial services
firm, you have mortgages,
you have credit cards,

you have all of these, you
have investment advice,

you have all of these
different business areas

that may be data producers
that are responsible
for producing data products in their area.

But if I need to understand
my total relationship

with the customer, that
data needs to join together.

It's not just about putting
that data on one platform.

It's not just about
providing a data catalog.
It is about doing all of the things

around data management
that we talked about.

So, it's things like,
are the joins gonna work?

When I joined data together,
is that gonna work?
Do I have a consistent list of products

and customers that cuts across
my various business units?
Again, not just because it's a good idea,
but because it's absolutely essential

to support the targeted
business initiatives
that we're dealing with.

This is where companies
are having a real struggle

when it comes to excessive
decentralization.
Overcorrecting the bottleneck problem
by distributing too much responsibility
both to consumers and to producers.
So, what we need to make sure of
is that the central data team,

the central and the data
governance program within that

is looking around all of the
data management capabilities

and distributing their
responsibilities as much as possible,
but no more than that.
No more than that.

They've gotta take on
enough responsibility

for the things that will
not happen automatically
by data producers.
It requires, there's no way around it.
Linking data together
and making sure let's say, the math works,
when you're adding up sales and revenue

and things like that,
the math has to work.

Or if you're joining customer
data to transactions,
those joins don't just work technically,
they have to work semantically.
It has to make sense.
That requires proactive coordination
from the central data governance group.
And again, this is something
that is very significantly missed.
It's very often missed in organizations

that have gone from a
centralized organization
to a decentralized organization.
They've overcorrected in many cases.
We have to be very careful about that.
So, an example I'd like to use here
is let's take amazon.com.

So, in Amazon's history,
we built up a website

to sell books initially, and
then a lot of other products.
And over time, with a lot of success,
the system to support amazon.com

became very large and and
very difficult to manage.
So, famously, Amazon made the decision
to bust up the architecture

and bust up the organization
into two pizza teams
and into microservices architectures
and different things that
allow Amazon to scale more effectively

and to isolate changes
and things like that.
However, if you go to amazon.com,
you have a consistent user experience.
We don't make it visible to the customer
what our internal organization
and team structures look like.
They shouldn't have to worry about that.

For the customer, it should be
a consistent user experience.
So, for example, the different teams

within Amazon will leverage
one shopping cart module.
There's a five-star review system.
All the detail pages look the same.
There's relationships among the products
and how they relate to each other.
When you are an Amazon customer,
you're getting a coherent experience

and you're navigating the
site as if it is one company,
which it is, even if under the surface,
there are a variety of two pizza teams

helping to make that
work in a scalable way.

Now, we don't wanna overcorrect
in the other direction.
So, let's take for example, Twitch.
Twitch is a video streaming service
that is wholly owned by Amazon.
And it is a different user experience.
It's a different user experience
and that's by design, that's by intention.

So, if we were to attempt
to organize all data

under the covers to link
every aspect of Twitch

with every aspect of amazon.com,
well, that's not a part

of the business vision
associated with those.

So, we would be overdoing
it towards centralization.

And this is, once again,
why it is so crucial
to match the vision for data
with the vision for the business.
Again, driven by specific initiatives.

So, as you look at your
business initiatives

that are in front of you, you're
gonna see a certain breadth
of the organization that it covers.
Some will be completely enterprise-wide,

some will be contained within
specific business units.
And you'll see some patterns over time.
And through that, you're gonna be able

to determine what is
the right distribution
of responsibilities between the data team,

between data consumers,
and data producers.

And in all of those areas
between IT and the business
for reasons we've talked about previously,
data management is always a partnership

between IT and the business
for each of these areas.
So, that's why it's so important to,
again, be driven by business initiatives.

Think about the right
distribution of responsibilities.

As you are deploying data
management practices,
you're doing it in the right way
to distribute responsibilities
across the organization effectively

and doing it little by little
over time, making adjustments.
If you make mistakes, no problem.
But you can course-correct based on the,
again, targeted initiatives

and the roadmap that we
talked about previously.
